message_1: In the design of a survey, a researcher wants to ensure that each of the 6 questions is asked to each of the 10 participants. How many different ways can the survey be constructed to ensure this requirement is met?
message_2:
If each of the 6 questions is asked to each of the 10 participants, then each participant will answer all 6 questions. The order in which the questions are asked to each participant can vary. 

For the first participant, there are 6 questions that can be asked first, then 5 remaining questions that can be asked second, 4 remaining questions that can be asked third, and so on. So, for the first participant, there are 6! (6 factorial) ways to ask the questions.

Similarly, for each of the other 9 participants, there are also 6! ways to ask the questions.

Since there are 10 participants, the total number of ways to construct the survey is:

(6!)^10 = (720)^10 ≈ 2.601 × 10^27 different ways.
